title: OZ copper sales rebound as strikes, protests hurt rivals
text:
OZ's cash balance rose by $9 million over the quarter, despite paying a dividend and continuing to invest in Carrapateena, to $195 million.

The extra sales come as about 3 per cent of global copper supply is disrupted; MMG's Las Bambas mine in Peru is being hampered by road blockades, North American miners Teck and Asarco are suffering workplace strikes.

Ecuador's Mirador copper mine has also been affected by large scale protests in the nation, which have sparked a halving of the share price of Ecuador focused SolGold; the explorer that BHP and Newcrest Mining have bought stakes in.

OZ remains on track to achieve its copper production guidance in 2019, with the company promising to produce at least 103,000 tonnes of copper, despite a weaker performance in terms of underground material movement.

OZ has also lowered expected unit costs at its flagship Prominent Hill mine.

Copper was fetching $US2.59 per pound on Wednesday.

OZ chief Andrew Cole said 2020 would be a ramp up year for Carrapateena, with the mine set to run spasmodically, with temporary closures and continued spending on the asset.

Mr Cole said he did not expect Carrapateena to be cashflow positive in 2020.

''It is still a high investment year for Carrapateena... Carrapateena won't be cash positive next year,'' he told analysts on Wednesday morning.

RBC analyst Paul Hissey said OZ should be able to achieve its goal of continuing to pay dividends through the period it was spending on development of Carrapateena.

''On our estimates, OZ can continue funding the remaining development capital (about $280 million) from its existing and operating cash flows,'' he said on Wednesday.
description: OZ Minerals sold more copper than it produced in the past three months, easing concerns about customer deferrals in early 2019.
